title: Sen. Schiff On What Democrats Need To Do To Compete In Red States And Districts

want to say I hope Have a seat, y'all. I
hope you had a chance I hope all of you
had a chance to see my interview with

famously doesn't do interviews like

It has
since the last time you were here. You

You're welcome. And it's called the It's

when you visit the red districts in your
state, do you do you ever think the
people there are ever surprised that you
are not uh the shrieking demon that
Donald Trump portrays you as?
Oh, absolutely. I asked for a position
on the agriculture committee. We're the
number one egg producing state of the
union, but we haven't had a senator on a
in 30 years. And part of the reason I
wanted to do it is this is a super
important industry for the state, for
the country. Um, but also because it
would give me a window into what the
deep red parts of California are like,
what folks are thinking, how I can serve
them, how I can relate to them. And on
one of my visits recently to But
in the far northeast of the state, it's
part of California that wants to secede
and become its own red state. Um, I met
with the Farm Bureau, uh, very
conservative group in in that
conservative part of the state, and I
could tell they were kind of
standoffish, a little suspicious. What
did this big city Democrat want? Meeting
with the But Carney Farm Bureau. Uh, and
after a while, you know, they warmed up.
I said, "Look, I'm just here to learn. I
want to represent you. I want to fight
for you in the Senate." Uh, and by the
end of the meeting, I could tell I'd
made progress because one of the farmers
turned to me and said, "I don't know why
the president calls you watermelon head.
You have a perfectly normalsized head."
And and Stephen, that's how we do it.
That's how we bridge the gap. One inch
at a time.
Yes. We we
one watermelon head at a time.
We we come to agreement on the size of
my head. And uh
well, you you spent so much time
investigating Donald Trump and sounding
the alarm on his misdeeds, the the
Russell collusion, impeachment, January
6th. I mean, and obviously you love your
state, you respect the the the people in

there are parts of your state that went
for Donald Trump during this last

they didn't see that other people saw in
those that first term? Well, you know,
one of the the uh things that's apparent
as I visit these deep red parts of
California is, you know, there's a
cultural divide as there is in much of
the country. Um there are also divisions
over real substantive issues in
California fights over water between
farmers and between environmentalists.
Uh but a big part of it too, and this to
me is maybe one of the most important
takeaways is we just haven't competed
there. We haven't shown up there. We
haven't introduced ourselves. we haven't
tried to uh you know make sure that
people understand we want to represent
them. Uh people aren't going to vote for
you. They're not going to support you if
they think you look down on them or
condescend to them or even worse you're
not interested and you're just
indifferent to them. So I think um all
over the country Democrats need to be
pressing the case in every part of the
country realizing we're not going to win
everyone over but there are a lot of
people we can win over. uh they are
surprised when they meet me. They
they've seen this caricature of me on
Fox. Uh they've heard, you know, only
about me from the president. Uh and it's
kind of a revelation when I don't turn
out to have horns. So, this is, you
know, this is part of what I think it
takes to compete.
We have to take a quick break. We'll be
right back with more Senator Adam
Schiff. Everybody stick around.
